newsitem.title: SPAIN: BA increases cargo capacity ex-Madrid.
newsitem.headline: BA increases cargo capacity ex-Madrid.

text.p: British Airways Plc is preparing to replace narrowbodies with widebodied aircraft on one or two of its seven daily flights to London from Madrid, BA cargo manager Vicente Das said.

"There will be a 767 on at least one and probably two of the daily flights," Das told Reuters. "We are waiting for confirmation from London," and this would mean a significant increase in cargo capacity.

BA currently uses Boeing 757s, 737s and Airbus A320s on its Madrid flights and 767s only at weekends. A Boeing 757, for example, will typically carry between two and three tonnes of cargo, Das said, while a 767 can accommodate pallets and loads of 14 or 15 tonnes.
BA's Spanish cargo business has been strong so far this financial year, Das said. The growth is in volume terms as prices have hardly changed.
"Revenues in August were 40 or 50 percent above those of the same period 1995 and prices are practically the same as last year," Das said.
"Business is much better than last year. There's been a rise in practically all the destinations where we operate."
All cargo from Spain passes through BA's Heathrow hub for onward transfer. Besides Madrid, the airline has flights from Barcelona, Malaga, Valencia, Bilbao, Murcia and Jerez.
Cargo traffic from the last two is practically non-existent but the major destinations provide a wide range of goods for air export. - Air Cargo Newsroom Tel+44 171 542 7706 Fax+44 171 542 5017
